Too many times to count:

-Parrots Kremlin talking points
-Denies Russian election interference in 2016
-Refuses to take any key steps to protect our upcoming elections

October 2019: Announces his intention to withdraw from the Open Skies Treaty ‚Äì which infuriates our allies and would eliminate a key channel for transparency that prevents Russia and the U.S. from stumbling into a war.
October 2019: Abruptly pulls U.S. troops out of northeastern Syria ‚Äì abandoning our Kurdish partners and creating a vacuum for Assad and Russia to fill.
August 2019: Holds up nearly $400 million in military assistance to Ukraine ‚Äì critical aid they needed to help fendoff Russia ‚Äì to try and force them to manufacture dirt on a 2020 rival.
August 2019: Withdraws from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, upending decades of bilateral work on nuclear arms control.
January 2019: Lifts election interference sanctions on Oleg Deripaska (a Russian billionaire with ties to Paul Manafort), despite no changes in Russia's behavior.
July 2018: The Helsinki summit. Trump again sides with Putin over U.S. intelligence agencies re: 2016 and invites him to the White House.
June 2018: Recognizes Crimea as part of Russia, as he first suggested on the campaign trail in 2016. The ultimate gift to Putin.
February 2017: Refuses to criticize Putin‚Äôs murder of political opponents. Direct quote from Trump: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got a lot of killers. What do you think, our country‚Äôs so innocent?‚Äù
January 2017: From the beginning, Trump and his officials refuse to stand up the capabilities of the Global Engagement Center to combat Russian propaganda and disinformation.
December 2016: Trump ‚Äì despite a clear consensus across 17 U.S. intelligence agencies ‚Äì denies Russian interference in the 2016 elections.
July 2016: The Trump campaign scraps language in the Republican platform on giving Ukraine military assistance to counter Russian forces.
May 2016: Questions U.S. commitment to NATO (aka the defense pact that prevents against Russian aggression).
May 2016: Announces his support for Brexit. Who benefits from a weaker EU? Russia.

Today I'll be asking questions at the nomination hearing of our new Amb. to Russia.

5/ But we knew that this would enrage the Turks (and it did), but we just closed our eyes to the coming political nightmare. We had 1 (yes, ONE) diplomat in northern Syria for much of 2015-17 trying to figure out the politics of post-ISIS northern Syria.

4/ Our real interest all along was defeating ISIS. And with the Turks unwilling to help, and our justifiable reluctance to send hundreds of thousands of U.S. troops into Syria (creating another Iraq-like disaster), we rightly turned to the Kurds and the SDF to do the job.

3/ But our hubris led to us to believe that tepid, mostly secret support to the rebels could do the job. All it did was prolong the war, without ever being enough to help them win. We dragged the war on needlessly, and misled the rebels about what we were prepared to do.

2/ First, contrary to the belief of much of the establishment, there was no magic moment in 2011/12 when U.S. could have put our muscle behind the rebels to topple Assad. From the start, Iran/Russia had more at stake than us, & they were always going to do more than us to win.
